title: Overseas Chinese Affairs Office provides funds to renovate the Third Chinese Primary School in Pyongyang (Linked to Project ID#66106)
description: In 2018, the Overseas Chinese Affairs Office provided funds to renovate the Third Chinese Primary School in Pyongyang. The renovation began in 2018 and was completed by August 30, 2018. The renovation was said to have improve the school's physical conditions and teaching environment port of financial support for a comprehensive renovation. The monetary value of this financial support is unknown.  Third Chinese Primary School is located in Sadong-guyok (Sadong District) of Pyongyang and is dedicated to the education of the children of overseas Chinese families. The Chinese Embassy in North Korea donated office supplies to the school on August 30, 2018, as captured by linked project ID#66106.
staff_comments: The Chinese name of the school is 第三中国人小学.
combined_text:

The renovation was said to have improve the school's physical conditions and teaching environment port of financial support for a comprehensive renovation. The monetary value of this financial support is unknown.  Third Chinese Primary School is located in Sadong-guyok (Sadong District) of Pyongyang and is dedicated to the education of the children of overseas Chinese families. The Chinese Embassy in North Korea donated office supplies to the school on August 30, 2018, as captured by linked project ID#66106.
justification: Project focuses on education infrastructure renovation without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Renovation of primary school, improvement of teaching environment, education focus

title: Chinese Government donates 525,000 tons of crude oil in 2018
description: In 2018, the Chinese Government donated approximately 525,000 tons of crude oil to the North Korean Government. 525,000 tons of oil is equivalent to 3,832,500 barrels of oil. Therefore, to estimate the monetary value of this donation ($249,993,975), AidData has taken the average price ($65.23) of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate (NYMEX) crude oil in 2018 and multiplied it by 3,832,500 barrels of oil. This crude oil donation project was supported via recurring grants from China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) between 2000 and 2018.  Since 1991, China has been North Korea's largest crude oil provider, making up 80% of its supply. Crude oil is provided to North Korea through a pipeline (known as the Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline or Friendship Oil Pipeline) from the Daqing Oil Field, 800 kilometers north of the China-North Korea border. The pipeline, which was completed in December 1975, runs for more than 30 km from storage facilities in the Chinese border city of Dandong to an oil depot in Sinuiju in North Korea. It supplies approximately 520,000 tons (3.64 million barrels) of heavy crude oil each year, according to its operator, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC). Once across the border, the crude oil is processed at North Korea's sole working refinery, the Ponghwa Chemical Factory, a facility built with Chinese assistance during the 1970s. The refinery turns the oil into refined products for North Korea's government, military, transport, agricultural and fishing sectors.  China’s provision of oil to North Korea — through the Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline (or ‘Friendship Oil Pipeline’) — was exempted from the sanctions that the United Nations Security Council imposed on North Korea in December 2017. In Paragraph 4 of resolution 2397 (2017), the United Nations Security Council decided that all Member States should prohibit the direct or indirect supply, sale or transfer of crude oil to the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea (North Korea) exceeding 4 million barrels or 525,000 tons, unless it approved in advance on a case-by-case basis for a 12-month period after the date of adoption of the resolution (December 22, 2017). Pursuant to the reporting clause contained therein, the Chinese Government reported that the amount of the supply of crude oil by China to the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea was 150,500 tons from December 2017 to February 2018; 147,900 tons from March to May 2018; 108,500 tons from June to August 2018; and 118,100 tons from September to November 2018. These deliveries sum to precisely 525,000 tons of crude oil.
staff_comments: 1. In 2012, a North Korean source disclosed that every year ‘the Ministry of Commerce of China and the North Korean government will discuss the catalogue of aid products, quantity, period, etc., but it is basically 100,000 tons of grain, 500,000 tons of oil, and materials needed by North Korea worth 20 million US dollars.’ This annual oil donation arrangement between the Chinese Government and the North Korean Government dates back to the 1970s. On October 17, 1970, the Chinese Government and the Government of North Korea signed an Agreement on Mutual Supply of Critical Materials 1971-1976. Under the terms of this agreement, the Chinese Government agreed to provide the North Korean Government with 500,000 tons of crude oil per year. 2. One metric ton of crude oil is equivalent to roughly 7.3 barrels of crude oil. 3. AidData assumes that all of the 2018 crude oil deliveries that the Chinese Government voluntarily disclosed to the United National Security Council were donated rather than sold (per the longstanding oil donation arrangement between the Chinese Government and the North Korean Government). 4. In August 2021, analysis of satellite imagery provided evidence of Chinese and North Korean efforts to repair and/or expand the 47-year-old Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline (‘Friendship Oil Pipeline’) near the border between the countries. At that time, it was unclear if the effort was indicative of difficulty transporting crude oil from China to North Korea through the pipeline and a shift towards the supply of refined petroleum products via offshore (ship-to-ship) transfers. However, multiple United Nations Security Council reports provide evidence of an increase in illicit ship-to-ship transfers of refined petroleum products circa 2019/2020. This issue warrants further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
Chinese Government donates 525,000 tons of crude oil in 2018

# Description
In 2018, the Chinese Government donated approximately 525,000 tons of crude oil to the North Korean Government. 525,000 tons of oil is equivalent to 3,832,500 barrels of oil. Therefore, to estimate the monetary value of this donation ($249,993,975), AidData has taken the average price ($65.23) of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate (NYMEX) crude oil in 2018 and multiplied it by 3,832,500 barrels of oil. This crude oil donation project was supported via recurring grants from China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) between 2000 and 2018.  Since 1991, China has been North Korea's largest crude oil provider, making up 80% of its supply. Crude oil is provided to North Korea through a pipeline (known as the Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline or Friendship Oil Pipeline) from the Daqing Oil Field, 800 kilometers north of the China-North Korea border. The pipeline, which was completed in December 1975, runs for more than 30 km from storage facilities in the Chinese border city of Dandong to an oil depot in Sinuiju in North Korea. It supplies approximately 520,000 tons (3.64 million barrels) of heavy crude oil each year, according to its operator, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC). Once across the border, the crude oil is processed at North Korea's sole working refinery, the Ponghwa Chemical Factory, a facility built with Chinese assistance during the 1970s. The refinery turns the oil into refined products for North Korea's government, military, transport, agricultural and fishing sectors.  China’s provision of oil to North Korea — through the Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline (or ‘Friendship Oil Pipeline’) — was exempted from the sanctions that the United Nations Security Council imposed on North Korea in December 2017. In Paragraph 4 of resolution 2397 (2017), the United Nations Security Council decided that all Member States should prohibit the direct or indirect supply, sale or transfer of crude oil to the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea (North Korea) exceeding 4 million barrels or 525,000 tons, unless it approved in advance on a case-by-case basis for a 12-month period after the date of adoption of the resolution (December 22, 2017). Pursuant to the reporting clause contained therein, the Chinese Government reported that the amount of the supply of crude oil by China to the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea was 150,500 tons from December 2017 to February 2018; 147,900 tons from March to May 2018; 108,500 tons from June to August 2018; and 118,100 tons from September to November 2018. These deliveries sum to precisely 525,000 tons of crude oil.
justification: Project involves donation of crude oil, a fossil fuel, supporting North Korea's energy infrastructure and military/industrial complex
evidence: 525,000 tons of crude oil donation, supplied through existing oil pipeline infrastructure, processed at North Korean refinery for military and industrial use

title: Chinese government funds rehabilitation of Congolese National Library
description: At some point prior to 2018, Chinese government funded the rehabilitation of the Congolese National Library in Democratic Republic of Congo. The commitment date is unclear, but the project was completed on August 8, 2018. Wang Tongqing, the Chinese Ambassador to the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and Mattia, Minister of Culture of the Congo, attended the completion ceremony. The amount of the funding is unknown.
staff_comments: The commitment date as well as exact implementation start date is unclear.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese government funds rehabilitation of Congolese National Library

# Description
At some point prior to 2018, Chinese government funded the rehabilitation of the Congolese National Library in Democratic Republic of Congo. The commitment date is unclear, but the project was completed on August 8, 2018. Wang Tongqing, the Chinese Ambassador to the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and Mattia, Minister of Culture of the Congo, attended the completion ceremony. The amount of the funding is unknown.
justification: Project focuses on cultural infrastructure without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Rehabilitation of national library, categorized under social infrastructure and services

title: China Eximbank provides $298.88 million preferential buyer’s credit for Kinsuka 220KV Substation and Associated Distribution Networks Project (Linked to Project ID#460)
description: On October 28, 2018, China Eximbank and the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo signed a $298,880,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC NO (2018) TOTAL NO 480] for the Kinsuka 220KV Substation and Associated Distribution Networks Project (captured via Project ID#59085). The PBC (loan) carries the following borrowing terms: a 20 year maturity, a 7 year grace period, a 2% interest rate, and a 0.75% commitment fee. The loan's (principal) amount outstanding was $52,743,617.40 in 2021 and 2022.    The purpose of the project is to evacuate power from the 150MW Zongo II Hydroelectric Dam, which was financed through a separate China Eximbank PBC (captured via Project ID#460).  The project involves the construction of the 220KV substation in Kinsuka commune and associated medium and low voltage distribution networks in the west of Kinshasa (in the municipalities of Mont Ngafula  and Ngaliema).   Shanghai Electric Group is the general EPC contractor responsible for implementation. Taichang Electric and Société Nationale d’Electricité (SNEL) are also involved in project implementation.  A formal groundbreaking ceremony took place on July 27, 2021. However, construction reportedly began several months earlier in April 2021. By May 2023, the project was nearing completion and China's Ambassador to the DRC announced that Kinsuka substation would transmit power to nearly two million residents in the capital Kinshasa (approximately 6 months before DRC President Tshisekedi would stand for re-election).
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the construction of the Kinsuka 220KV substation and associated medium and low voltage distribution networks project and the Kinsuka Substation and Associated Distribution Network Project. The French project title is Construction du poste 220KV de Kinsuka et des réseaux de distrubution moyenne et basse tension associés (pour la connexion de Zongo ll). The Chinese project title is 金苏卡变电站升级改造项目 or 金苏卡220千伏变电站及相关配网项目. 2. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the 2020 version of the China’s Global Energy Finance database published by Boston University. 3. In the database of Chinese loan commitments that SAIS-CARI released in July 2020, the borrowing terms of the China Eximbank loan for the Kinsuka 220KV Substation and Associated Distribution Networks Project are not identified. AidData relies on the borrowing terms recorded by the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (via https://dgdp-rdc.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/DGDP-Rapport-Annuel-2018.pdf).
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provides $298.88 million preferential buyer’s credit for Kinsuka 220KV Substation and Associated Distribution Networks Project (Linked to Project ID#460)

# Description
On October 28, 2018, China Eximbank and the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo signed a $298,880,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC NO (2018) TOTAL NO 480] for the Kinsuka 220KV Substation and Associated Distribution Networks Project (captured via Project ID#59085). The PBC (loan) carries the following borrowing terms: a 20 year maturity, a 7 year grace period, a 2% interest rate, and a 0.75% commitment fee. The loan's (principal) amount outstanding was $52,743,617.40 in 2021 and 2022.    The purpose of the project is to evacuate power from the 150MW Zongo II Hydroelectric Dam, which was financed through a separate China Eximbank PBC (captured via Project ID#460).  The project involves the construction of the 220KV substation in Kinsuka commune and associated medium and low voltage distribution networks in the west of Kinshasa (in the municipalities of Mont Ngafula  and Ngaliema).   Shanghai Electric Group is the general EPC contractor responsible for implementation. Taichang Electric and Société Nationale d’Electricité (SNEL) are also involved in project implementation.  A formal groundbreaking ceremony took place on July 27, 2021. However, construction reportedly began several months earlier in April 2021. By May 2023, the project was nearing completion and China's Ambassador to the DRC announced that Kinsuka substation would transmit power to nearly two million residents in the capital Kinshasa (approximately 6 months before DRC President Tshisekedi would stand for re-election).
justification: Primary purpose is electricity transmission infrastructure, enabling power distribution from a renewable energy source
evidence: Construction of 220KV substation and associated distribution networks, specifically designed to evacuate power from Zongo II Hydroelectric Dam

title: Chinese Government dispatches 18th medical team to Sino-Congolese Friendship Hospital in N'djili.
description: On May 23, 2018, the 18th Medical Team dispatched from Hong Kong by the Chinese Government arrived at the Democratic Republic of Congo. The 18th medical team captain was named by the Chinese Embassy in DRC to be Liu Fu (刘福) and he had met with the 17th medical team captain Wang Junhui (王俊辉) and the Chinese Ambassador to DRC, Wang Tongqing (王同庆) on May 28, 2018 during a handover meeting. The 18th medical team consists of 18 experts from five cities in Hebei Province, including Shijiazhuang, Baoding, Xingtai, Handan and Tangshan, and they will serve at Sino-Congolese Friendship Hospital in N'djili for two years. The team's main task is to conduct medical visits, conduct operations, etc., and provide professional training for local medical staff.  The Chinese Government has been sending medical teams to the Democratic Republic of Congo since 1973. However, due to internal turmoil, the Chinese Government stopped sending medical teams from 1997 to 2008. Hebei Province has been responsible for sending the medical teams.
staff_comments: The exact end date of the 18th medical team is unclear, but the 19th team arrived in DRC in June 8th, 2020.The Chinese Government also provided an RMB 48 million grant for the construction of the Sino-Congolese Friendship Hospital (Project ID#438).
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government dispatches 18th medical team to Sino-Congolese Friendship Hospital in N'djili.

# Description
On May 23, 2018, the 18th Medical Team dispatched from Hong Kong by the Chinese Government arrived at the Democratic Republic of Congo. The 18th medical team captain was named by the Chinese Embassy in DRC to be Liu Fu (刘福) and he had met with the 17th medical team captain Wang Junhui (王俊辉) and the Chinese Ambassador to DRC, Wang Tongqing (王同庆) on May 28, 2018 during a handover meeting. The 18th medical team consists of 18 experts from five cities in Hebei Province, including Shijiazhuang, Baoding, Xingtai, Handan and Tangshan, and they will serve at Sino-Congolese Friendship Hospital in N'djili for two years. The team's main task is to conduct medical visits, conduct operations, etc., and provide professional training for local medical staff.  The Chinese Government has been sending medical teams to the Democratic Republic of Congo since 1973. However, due to internal turmoil, the Chinese Government stopped sending medical teams from 1997 to 2008. Hebei Province has been responsible for sending the medical teams.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare services and medical training, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical team deployment, healthcare services, professional training for local medical staff

title: Chinese government awards government scholarships to 60 Congolese students to study in China for 2018/2019 academic year.
description: On August 17, 2018, Chinese Ambassador to DRC Wang Tongqing awarded Congolese 60 students scholarships to study in China for the 2018/2019 academic year. The awards were provided to the students at a farewell ceremony in Kinshasa, with total attendance of approximately 100 members, including DRC's Minister of Higher and University Education (ESU), Mr. Steve Mbikayi, alongside other DRC government representatives and university representatives.

title: [EBOLA] Chinese Embassy in Democratic Republic of Congo provides $1 million in cash assistance to the Government of the DRC for fighting Ebola outbreak
description: On May 29, 2018, the Chinese Embassy in DRC provided a check worth USD $1 million to the Government of the DRC for emergency assistance in fighting the Ebola outbreak in the country. At the handover ceremony hosted at the DRC's Ministry of Foreign Affairs the dignitaries in attendance included Ambassador Wang Tongqing, DRC's Foreign Minister Okitundu, and the DRC's Minister of Health Irenga among other respective government officials.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
[EBOLA] Chinese Embassy in Democratic Republic of Congo provides $1 million in cash assistance to the Government of the DRC for fighting Ebola outbreak

# Description
On May 29, 2018, the Chinese Embassy in DRC provided a check worth USD $1 million to the Government of the DRC for emergency assistance in fighting the Ebola outbreak in the country. At the handover ceremony hosted at the DRC's Ministry of Foreign Affairs the dignitaries in attendance included Ambassador Wang Tongqing, DRC's Foreign Minister Okitundu, and the DRC's Minister of Health Irenga among other respective government officials.
justification: Cash assistance for emergency response to a health crisis, unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Emergency assistance for Ebola outbreak, cash transfer for health crisis response

title: China funds expansion of “Children’s Smile” orphanage in the Democratic Republic of Congo
description: On January 28, 2018, a handover ceremony of the expanded “Children’s Smile” orphanage, which was funded by the Chinese embassy, Chinese Enterprises Association, and the Federation of Overseas Chinese, was held in Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo.  The project included an expansion of the orphanage. The Chinese Enterprises Association also donated daily necessities to the orphanage. The value of the donation and when construction began are unknown.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is “儿童微笑”孤儿院院舍扩建项目.

title: [Sino-Congolese Programme] China Eximbank provides $5 million loan for Phase 2 of Uvira Road Rehabilitation and Modernization Project (Linked to Project ID#450, #46235)
description: In 2008, China Eximbank issued a $3 billion line of credit to Sino–Congolais des Mines (Sicomines SARL) — a joint venture — to finance infrastructure projects in the DRC (see Project ID#450). All borrowings through this line of credit (framework agreement) are repaid with revenues from mining projects managed by Sicomines SARL. Each subsidiary loan issued through the line of credit carries a maturity of 25 years, a grace period of 10 years, and an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR plus a 1% margin (or 3.839% at the time of the agreement). The infrastructure projects that are supported by this line of credit are collectively referred to as the ‘Sino-Congolese Programme’. The Government of Democratic Republic of Congo issued a sovereign guarantee for all infrastructure loans approved through the ‘Sino-Congolese Programme’ line of credit.   One of the subsidiary loans issued as part of the 'Sino-Congolese Programme' was a $5 million loan for Phase 2 of the Uvira Road Rehabilitation and Modernization Project. The loan ultimately achieved a disbursement rate of 96% ($4,824,815.43 out of $5,000,000). The project involved the rehabilitation and modernization of 9.55km of highways and roads of the city of Uvira in South Kivu Province. Specifically, this project will involve the rehabilitation of the Uvira crossing, which runs 9.55km from the port of Kalundu to the Kavinvira roundabout.   Sinohydro is the contractor responsible for project implementation. It was awarded a $5 million contract (ID#ACGT/DG/009/2018) on November 30, 2018. Phase 2 of Uvira Road Rehabilitation and Modernization Project has entered implementation. However, it does not appear to have reached completion. The project’s originally scheduled completion date was April 2, 2019.
staff_comments: 1. The French project title is Modernisation de la Voirie d’Uvira. 2. In 2017, the Government of the Democratic of Congo requested addition funding worth $17,546,236.06. The 2018 ACGT Annual Report still only records the 2015 committed amount, $5 million USD, which is presumably the reason for the delay in project implementation. 3. Phase 1 of the Uvira Road Rehabilitation and Modernization Project is captured via Project ID#46235.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
[Sino-Congolese Programme] China Eximbank provides $5 million loan for Phase 2 of Uvira Road Rehabilitation and Modernization Project (Linked to Project ID#450, #46235)

# Description
In 2008, China Eximbank issued a $3 billion line of credit to Sino–Congolais des Mines (Sicomines SARL) — a joint venture — to finance infrastructure projects in the DRC (see Project ID#450). All borrowings through this line of credit (framework agreement) are repaid with revenues from mining projects managed by Sicomines SARL. Each subsidiary loan issued through the line of credit carries a maturity of 25 years, a grace period of 10 years, and an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR plus a 1% margin (or 3.839% at the time of the agreement). The infrastructure projects that are supported by this line of credit are collectively referred to as the ‘Sino-Congolese Programme’. The Government of Democratic Republic of Congo issued a sovereign guarantee for all infrastructure loans approved through the ‘Sino-Congolese Programme’ line of credit.   One of the subsidiary loans issued as part of the 'Sino-Congolese Programme' was a $5 million loan for Phase 2 of the Uvira Road Rehabilitation and Modernization Project. The loan ultimately achieved a disbursement rate of 96% ($4,824,815.43 out of $5,000,000). Specifically, this project will involve the rehabilitation of the Uvira crossing, which runs 9.55km from the port of Kalundu to the Kavinvira roundabout.   Sinohydro is the contractor responsible for project implementation. It was awarded a $5 million contract (ID#ACGT/DG/009/2018) on November 30, 2018. Phase 2 of Uvira Road Rehabilitation and Modernization Project has entered implementation. However, it does not appear to have reached completion. The project’s originally scheduled completion date was April 2, 2019.
justification: Road rehabilitation project with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Rehabilitation and modernization of 9.55km of highways and roads, general infrastructure focus
